adjective.description: Having a hard shell or surface; = "hardshell".
Difficult to solve or penetrate; intractable. Now rare.
Originally and chiefly US. Strongly or rigorously committed, uncompromising, especially in one's adherence to religious or political principles; hard-line; conservative.
Hardened, insensitive, callous; not easily moved.
Of a book: hardbacked. Somewhat rare.

origin: Late 16th century; earliest use found in Thomas Moffett (1553–1604), physician and naturalist. From hard + shelled.
